title: Swordfish-Olive Pasta
summary: Swordfish-Olive Pastan is a dairy free and pescatarian recipe with 4 servings. One serving contains 606 calories, 42g of protein, and 26g of fat. For $4.38 per serving, this recipe covers 30% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. 1 person has made this recipe and would make it again. Head to the store and pick up onion, oregano, pasta, and a few other things to make it today. To use up the pasta you could follow this main course with the Chocolate Dessert Pasta as a dessert. Only a few people really liked this main course. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes roughly 30 minutes. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 74%. This score is solid. Try Swordfish With Olive, Pine Nut, And Parsley Relish, Seared Swordfish With Tomato-olive Sauce, and Grilled Swordfish Steaks With Olive Pesto for similar recipes.

winePairing.pairingText: No one wine will suit every pasta dish. Pasta in a tomato-based sauce will usually work well with a medium-bodied red, such as a montepulciano or chianti. Pasta with seafood or pesto will fare better with a light-bodied white, such as a pinot grigio. Cheese-heavy pasta can pair well with red or white - you might try a sangiovese wine for hard cheeses and a chardonnay for soft cheeses. We may be able to make a better recommendation if you ask again with a specific pasta dish.

instructions: Instructions                                                                                                                                                                                                                 Preheat the broiler and line the rack with aluminum foil. Broil the swordfish 3 minutes on one side, turn, top with the olives, and broil 4 minutes longer. In the meantime, pour the oil into a saut pan and cook the onion and garlic until they are soft. Add the oregano and capers.                                                    Cook and drain the pasta.                                                    When the fish is cooked, take it out of the broiler and cut it into thin strips. Spoon it and the olives, with the onion-caper mixture, over freshly cooked pasta and toss gently.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                var articleType_27_data = {};                    articleType_27_data.init_step_by_step_images = 0;

steps.step: Preheat the broiler and line the rack with aluminum foil. Broil the swordfish 3 minutes on one side, turn, top with the olives, and broil 4 minutes longer. In the meantime, pour the oil into a saut pan and cook the onion and garlic until they are soft.
When the fish is cooked, take it out of the broiler and cut it into thin strips. Spoon it and the olives, with the onion-caper mixture, over freshly cooked pasta and toss gently.
